slidelink.displaytext: Untitled Scene

Leukemia: mutation of stem cells in the bone marrow, causing impaired production of normal R B C’s, W B C’s, and platelets. A initial evaluation should be on symptoms, CBC and cell lineage.
Neoplastic cells crowding bone marrow causes a decrease in which cell line?

chromosomal translocation, which causes uncontrolled cellular proliferation May be caused by genetics or toxic exposure. Condition that can predispose of the leukemia is:
Down’s syndrome Fanconi’s anemia Recurrent exposure to benzene Exposure to ionizing radiation Chronic myeloproliferative disorders
What is the leukemia type?
What is the diagnose that helps identify AML?

In this condition, cells are:
Dysfunctional cells leading to fever and infection. Anemia occurs leading to fatigue and weakness Thrombocytopenia causes easy bruising, petechiae and mucosal bleeding. *Headache, Blindness, Gum infiltration, Joint pain, Heart palpitations.
Which condition does this features match?
CBC of AML What is a complete and matching profile of a AML patient?
CBC of AML In AML there are Blasts present and Auer rods. In which cell line are the Auer rods present?
To diagnise AML, how many WBCs should be classified in PS?
All are ways to distinguish Myeloblast from lymphoblast, except for:

Cytochemical Stains is used to identify lipids or enzyme within blast population and it is helpful in the diagnosis and classification of acute leukemias.
The stain is negative for which cell?

Cytochemical Stains Used to identify lipids or enzyme within blast population .
Cytochemical Reaction, What are the cellular element stained for Myeloperoxidase (M P O)?

Cytochemical Stains Used to identify lipids or enzyme within blast population .
What are the cellular element stained for Nonspecific esterase (N S E)

Cytochemical Stains Used to identify lipids or enzyme within blast population .
What are the cellular element stained for Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (T d T)

Cytochemical Stains Used to identify lipids or enzyme within blast population .
What are the cellular element stained for Specific esterase

Cytochemical Stains Used to identify lipids or enzyme within blast population .
What are the cellular element stained for Sudan black B (S B B)
Used to classify the clone of leukemic blasts using antibodies directed against cell surface markers. It helps to recommend appropriate therapy and can be correlated to prognosis.
Used to identify clonality Used to establish translocations and to identify gene mutations.

5% to 12% A M L cases, Morphology: Myeloblasts with abundant cytoplasm, Auer rods in the neutrophil lineage, Dysplastic neutrophilic features, Associated with good response to chemotherapy and long-term survival rates
Hypergranular promyelocytes Multiple Auer rods Some microgranular promyelocytes (may appear as promonocytes) Associated with D I C Treatment with A T R A has high curability rate
Monoblasts and promonocytes in B M and peripheral blood Often show pseudopodia Fine nuclear chromatin with one or more nuclei Azurophilic granules Cytoplasmic vacuoles
Auer rods Basophilia in B M and peripheral blood Myelocytic and erythroid dysplasia Poor prognosis
Elevated platelet count Hypogranular neutrophils and platelets Giant platelets and dwarf megakaryocytes Increased eosinophils, basophils in B M Poor prognosis and short survival
Rare condition Medium to large blasts Cytoplasmic pseudopod formation Prognosis is promising after A M L chemotherapy
Blast percentage is greater than 20% Dysplasia in at least two cell lines Dysplastic feature in neutrophils: Hypogranulation Hyposegmentation Pseudopelgeroid Bizarre segmented nuclei Pancytopenia

This non specified leukemia Little evidence of maturation beyond the blast stage M P O and S B B cytochemical stains are usually negative Auer rods are absent
C D 34, 38, H L A-D R

This Not Otherwise Specified leukemia, has Greater than 90% of the nonerythroid cells in the bone marrow are myeloblasts Auer rods may be present At least 5% of blasts stain positive for S B B and M P O
C D 13, 33, 34, 117

Myeloblasts with Auer rods 50% blasts M P O and S B B-positive
C D 13, 33, 34, 11b, 15

This Not Otherwise Specified leukemia, Monoblasts show pseudopod cytoplasmic extensions One to four nucleoli Strong N S E reaction, M P O-positive
C D 13, 33, 15, 65

This Not Otherwise Specified leukemia, has predominance of monoblasts or promonocytes Auer rods are absent Stain positive with N S E Monoblasts are M P O and S B B-negative Promonocytes maybe weakly positive with M P O and S B B C D 14, 4, 11b, 11c, 36, 64, 68 Poor prognosis, shorter duration of treatment response
This Not Otherwise Specified greater than 30% pronormoblasts Bizarre multinuleation Cytoplasmic vacuolization Megaloblastic nuclear changes P A S block positivity n R B C’s Reticulocytopenia

This Not Otherwise Specified we see At least 50% megakaryoblasts Pallor, weakness, excessive bleeding Dysplastic features of platelets Immature myeloid cells Blasts with cytoplasmic blebbing Giant, hypogranular platelets C D 41, 61, 42

This Not Otherwise Specified is a Rare May arise as a blastic transformation in patients with a preceding C M L Predominant circulating cell appears blast-like with 1 to 3 nucleoli and prominent coarse basophilic granules M P O, S B B, and N S E stains are negative C D 13, 33, 34 Special stains, immunophenotyping, and cytogenetic features distinguish from acute promyelocytic leukemia

This Not Otherwise Specified is a Rare Pancytopenia Marrow hyperplasia of erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic components combined with fibrosis Splenomegaly usually absent (differentiates from chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis) Positive for C D 34 Poor prognosis
Tumor found in lymph nodes, bone, G I tract, skin, or any soft tissue Positive for M P O, chloroacetate esterase, and N S E stains Positive for C D 30, 34, 56, 68, 99, and 117

Rare but aggressive tumor Medium-sized blasts with irregular nuclei, 1 to 2 small nucleoli, fine chromatin Cells produce large amount of alpha-interferon Cytopenias may be minimal early on but intensifies as disease progresses Prognosis is poor

An Acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage, is the one with morphologic, immunophenotypic and cytochemical findinds not helpful in the classification of a particular type of myeloid or lymphoid process.
What are keys to identify them?

This is a malignant disease that is caused by a mutation of lymphoid precursor cells Results in Anemia Thrombocytopenia Neutropenia Overpopulation of lymphoblasts in the tissues Liver, spleen, lymph nodes, meninges, gonads
Variable W B C Anemia Thrombocytopenia S B B and M P O stain negative Lymphoblasts are T d T-pos, H L A-D R pos, and P A X-pos C D 10, C D 19, C D 20, C D 24, C D 22, C D 79a
Associated hyperleukocytosis, frequent C N S disease, and resistance to chemotherapy treatment. Worst prognosis of all the A L L’s.
Increases in frequency as age increases in adulthood Markedly elevated W B C and C N S involvement are the negative prognostic indicators
Accounts for 25% of B-A L L in children
Hyperdiploidy can be detected by Karyotyping Flow cytometry In situ hybridization analysis
Prognosis depends on the number of chromosomes A L L’s with 44 to 45 chromosomes have the best prognosis A L L’s with near-haploid number of chromosomes have a poor prognosis
C D 19-positive and C D 10-positive lymphoblasts Presence of peripheral blood eosinophilia
C D 19-positive and C D 10-positive Cytoplasmic mu heavy chain positive Current therapy has produced more promising prognosis

High risk pediatric A L L intrachromosomal amplification of chromosome 21 Amplification of 5 or more copies of the gene on a single abnormal portion of chromosome 21 Detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization methodology with a probe for the R U N X1 gene

Malignancy of lymphoblasts having T-lineage markers greater than 25% of bone marrow cells must be identified as lymphoblasts T-L B L if lymphoblasts primarily involves lymph nodes or extranodal sites Lymphoma if leukemic process is limited to a mass lesion or less than or equal to 2 lymphoblasts seen in B M

Malignancy of lymphoblasts having T-lineage markers greater than 25% of bone marrow cells must be identified as lymphoblasts T-L B L if lymphoblasts primarily involves lymph nodes or extranodal sites Lymphoma if leukemic process is limited to a mass lesion or less than or equal to 2 lymphoblasts seen in B M
Draw from Leukemia
Match the AML Myelodysplasia-Related Changes
